Hi!

I hope I understand correctly that you want to ensure that the listene=
rs are getting the right calls.

If yes, you should look into extensions li=
ke jmock, easymock,...

Cheers,
 Georg

--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "Lori=
tsch, Berin C." <berin.loritsch@...> wrote:
>
> I've got a challenge that I=
'm not sure how to approach with JUnit 4.
> I've sort of hacked something s=
imilar in JUnit3, but there were some
> inelegant things about it.
> 
> Bas=
ic problem is that I have a bunch of setters and getters on my domain
> mod=
els that have predictable side effects.  Essentially, the model has a
> lis=
tener infrastructure and if the user changes the value of the class
> attri=
bute the appropriate event is supposed to fire.  The typical
> setter/gette=
r looks like this:
> 
> class MyBean extends Listenable {
>     String valu=
e;
> 
>     public String getValue() {
>         return value;
>     }
> 
>=
     public void setValue(String newValue) {
>         fireAttributeChanged=
Event("value", value, newValue);
>         value =3D newValue;
>     }
> }
=
> 
> I need to test that the setters fire the appropriate event, and that t=
he
> event attribute name is correct.  I want a test harness to essentially=

> collect all the setters and getters and change the value to ensure that
=
> the event is sent as expected.  Then I want to run that against all my
> =
domain models.
> 
> My understanding is that I need to generate a suite, an=
d add the test
> instances to that suite.  I've upgraded to JUnit 4 because=
 I think it is
> designed better.  I'm just at a loss as to how to start.  =
With JUnit 4,
> individual tests are marked with an annotation.
